item.title: Norman Podhoretz, Influential Editor and Neoconservative Force, Dies at 95
item.description: A New York intellectual and onetime liberal stalwart, his Commentary magazine became his platform as his political and social view turned sharply rightward.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Norman Podhoretz in 1971.

item.title: Why Nick Reiner Could Face the Death Penalty
item.description: The two first-degree murder counts include a special circumstance, which increases the maximum punishment if he is convicted.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Nathan J. Hochman, the Los Angeles County district attorney, at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: New Details Emerge About How Rob and Michele Reiner Were Found
item.description: A person close to the family provided a detailed account of what occurred in the Reiner house after a massage therapist received no response at the gate.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Romy Reiner discovered the body of her father, Rob Reiner, inside the family’s mansion on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Judge Says He Will Not Immediately Halt Trump’s Ballroom Project
item.description: A federal judge said he would order the Trump administration to submit plans for the building by the end of the month, but allowed minor construction to continue for now.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction equipment for the new ballroom at the White House in November. President Trump’s vision for the project has steadily grown in scale from more modest proposals discussed in October.

item.title: Trump Expands Travel Ban and Restrictions to 20 More Countries
item.description: People from Syria, South Sudan and those with documents issued by the Palestinian Authority are included in the latest restrictions. More than 35 countries are now under U.S. travel restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beyond the travel restrictions, the ban could have major ramifications for nationals of those countries already in the United States.

item.title: Remixing Trump’s Economy Speech, Vance Strikes a Different Tone
item.description: Vice President JD Vance pleaded with everybody to just hang in there a little longer, saying the economy would improve.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance, on Tuesday in Allentown, Pa., said of the economy, “I know that there is so much more progress to be made.”

item.title: Nick Reiner Formally Charged With Murdering His Parents
item.description: Prosecutors said that Mr. Reiner killed his parents, Rob and Michelle Reiner, using a knife. He has not yet entered a plea.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Aude Guerrucci/Reuters
item.media:description: If convicted, Nick Reiner could be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole or the death penalty.

item.title: Two More Heritage Foundation Trustees Resign Over Support for Tucker Carlson
item.description: Three trustees have left since the think tank’s president backed the conservative podcaster’s friendly interview with Nick Fuentes.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington offices of the Heritage Foundation.

item.title: At Many Top Law Schools, Black Student Enrollment Continues to Drop
item.description: The New York Times examined data from 18 of the nation’s top law schools and found that first-year Black enrollment had increased at only four, including at Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Billy Hickey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard Law School in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Johnson Rules Out House Vote to Extend Health Insurance Subsidies
item.description: The speaker had planned to give moderate Republicans seeking an extension of the tax credits a vote on their proposal, but said on Tuesday it was simply “not to be.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson had signaled openness to allowing debate on the proposal to extend Affordable Care Act subsidies, but ultimately rejected a bid to do so by politically vulnerable Republicans.

item.title: Hegseth Declines to Show Lawmakers Boat Strike Video
item.description: The defense secretary joined the secretary of state on Capitol Hill to deliver the first classified briefings to include all members of the House and Senate on the maritime attacks.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed lawmakers on Tuesday on the military’s strikes on boats in international waters.

item.title: Alan Jackson, Nick Reiner’s Lawyer, Represented Harvey Weinstein, Karen Read and More
item.description: The lawyer, Alan Jackson, has represented the Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein and the actor Kevin Spacey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Tim Arango
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mark Stockwell
item.media:description: Alan Jackson in court defending Karen Read against a murder charge this year.

item.title: Wrong Turns and Long Nights: Inside the Search for the Brown University Attacker
item.description: After determining that a man they had detained was not the killer, Rhode Island officials have searched for more evidence and released photos of a possible gunman.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two people were killed and nine were injured in a shooting on Saturday at Brown University in Providence, R.I.

item.title: Trump and Top Aides Publicly Defend Susie Wiles After Explosive Interviews
item.description: President Trump praised his chief of staff as doing “a fantastic job,” and more than a dozen members of his cabinet have posted defenses of her on social media.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susie Wiles criticized the article as a “disingenuously framed hit piece” but did not deny the authenticity of the quotes.

item.title: U.S. Sends Cubans to Naval Station at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The transfer of nearly two dozen men this week restarted a Trump administration deportation operation on the base after a two-month hiatus.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: About 730 men have been held at the base by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, including this week’s arrivals.

item.title: M.I.T. Professor Is Fatally Shot in His Home
item.description: The professor, Nuno F.G. Loureiro, was pronounced dead at a hospital on Tuesday morning. The authorities said they had opened a homicide investigation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Scott Eisen/Getty Images
item.media:description: The professor, Nuno F.G. Loureiro, was the director of M.I.T.’s Plasma Science and Fusion Center.

item.title: Rob and Nick Reiner: A Father-Son Relationship in Several Acts
item.description: Some who worked on the semi-autobiographical “Being Charlie” saw challenges play out on the set.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll

item.title: Trump Stymied on Prosecutors as G.O.P. Refuses to Defy Democrats
item.description: An informal custom gives Senate Democrats leverage on federal prosecutors even as Republicans have sought to ease other confirmations. The president wants it eliminated.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Republicans’ refusal to abolish the “blue slip” is a rare area in which they have declined to go along with President Trump’s wishes.

item.title: White House Dismisses Rise in Unemployment
item.description: The Trump administration looked to recast elements of a dour jobs report Tuesday as a sign of strength.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The White House insisted on Tuesday that the economy remained strong under President Trump’s watch.

item.title: Takeaways From Susie Wiles’s Vanity Fair Interviews Describing Trump World
item.description: During 11 interviews with Vanity Fair over President Trump’s first year back in office, Ms. Wiles, his chief of staff, opened up about the president, the people around him and their internal fights.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susie Wiles, the White House chief of staff, typically shuns publicity. She called a recent article in Vanity Fair, based on 11 interviews she gave over the past year, “a disingenuously framed hit piece on me and the finest President, White House staff, and Cabinet in history.”

item.title: 3 Days After Deadly Brown Shooting, Killer and Motive Remain a Mystery
item.description: The authorities released more video footage in an attempt to identify a suspect, and said they had no idea why the killer attacked a study session.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Mitch Smith

item.title: Obamas Had Plans to See the Reiners the Day They Were Found Dead
item.description: Michelle Obama said on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” that she and former President Barack Obama were longtime friends of the couple and called them “decent, courageous” people.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michelle Obama speaking at an event in Washington last month.

item.title: The Timing of Trump’s $10 Billion Lawsuit Against the BBC Is Significant
item.description: The lawsuit landed just hours before a once-a-decade review of the broadcaster’s royal charter, which governs its mission, purpose and funding.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: The BBC has been the target of President Trump and his conservative allies in Britain, for what they consider to be its liberal bias.

item.title: Susie Wiles, Trump’s Chief of Staff, Criticizes Bondi and Vance in Candid Interviews
item.description: In interviews with Vanity Fair, Susie Wiles, the White House chief of staff, said President Trump “has an alcoholic’s personality,” called JD Vance a “conspiracy theorist” and concluded that Pam Bondi “completely whiffed” the early handling of the Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the course of 11 interviews, Ms. Wiles offered pungent assessments of the president and his team.

item.title: Days After Brown University Shooting, a Community Is in a Standstill
item.description: As a manhunt for a gunman who killed two and injured nine at Brown University stretched into a third day, residents and officials alike were growing weary.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents searching for clues near where footage showed a possible suspect walking away from the scene on Saturday.

item.title: Brown Shooting Tests a Fragile Trust on Campus
item.description: The Ivy League school has faced a series of challenges related to protests and politics. Through it all, it has kept its gates open to the city and tried to heal divisions on campus.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brown University has been open to the city around it. After last weekend’s shooting, some are asking if the school should do more to harden the campus to protect student safety.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Is a Focus of Trump’s Campaign Against Maduro
item.description: In public, the White House says it is confronting Venezuela to curb drug trafficking. Behind the scenes, gaining access to the country’s vast oil reserves is a priority.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil drilling equipment in Cabimas, Venezuela. The country has about 17 percent of the world’s known oil reserves, nearly four times the amount in the United States.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Matt Stevens, Tim Arango, Jill Cowan and Jesus Jiménez

item.title: Hospitals Cater to ‘Transplant Tourists’ as U.S. Patients Wait for Organs
item.description: International patients can bring a hospital as much as $2 million for a transplant. In recent years, they have typically gotten organs faster than U.S. patients.
item.dc:creator: Brian M. Rosenthal and Mark Hansen
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
